abstracts.cdata!:
This study of a medical waste management
            plan, was achieved within the framework of the HIV/AIDS
            Multisector Project in Burundi, and its analysis of
            management waste systems in medical institutions, renders
            the following findings: in mostly all institutions, medical
            waste management is exclusively confined to the cleaning
            staff members; most institutions do have brick incinerators,
            which are not functional due to lack of maintenance; there
            is no awareness on the importance of medical waste
            management within the medical personnel (medical wastes are
            often mixed with regular trash); and, a total absence of
            training prevails for medical waste management. Based on the
            analysis, this medical waste management plan suggest
            recommendations as follows. Legislation on medical, and
            biomedical waste management needs to be established,
            implemented, and enforced, regulated by waste management
            committees at the national, provincial, and municipal
            levels, with communal participation. In addition, hospitals
            and health care facilities should establish their own
            medical waste plans in compliance with the country's
            laws, and regulations, in order to set a governing
            institutional framework. Medical personnel should be trained
            in the management of the overall medical waste sector, and
            in addition, training should be further provided to staff
            members in charge of the institution's cleaning, and
            waste management practices. Public awareness should be
            raised, through community mobilization, and active
            participation of civil society, the private sector,
            organizations in general, and policymakers in particular, on
            the adequate management of biomedical wastes. Most
            importantly, electrical incinerators should replace existing
            ones, based on standard sanitary regulations, but to be
            later phased-out, and replaced by new waste treatment technologies.
